quoteFirst: We arrived in London after dark,
quoteLast: There we were met by some "Y" men, and after the identification of baggage, which with a hundred girls is a desperate affair, we were all loaded into huge trucks or "brakes" as they call them, and carted to our various destinations.
title: A "Y" Girl in France: Letters of Katherine Shortall
author: Shortall, Katherine

quoteFirst: The Dutch ship _Orange_, of seventy-five guns, was disabled after a sharp fight with the _Mary_, and was likewise burnt. Two Dutch vice-admirals were killed, and a panic spread through the Dutch Fleet.
quoteTime: About eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: between thirty and forty of their ships made off in a body, and the rest speedily followed. During the fight and the chase eighteen Dutch ships were taken, though some of these afterwards escaped, as the vessels to which they had struck joined the rest in the chase.
title: When London Burned : a Story of Restoration Times and the Great Fire
author: Henty, G. A. (George Alfred), 1832-1902

quoteFirst: , and to the northward of this lay some high land, which I took to be an island, and of which the north-west point bore 41 W.; but not being sure of a passage, I came to an anchor
quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: , in ten fathom water, with a muddy bottom. About ten we had a tide setting to the northward, and at two it had fallen nine feet; after this it began to rise, and the flood came from the northward, in the direction of the islands which lay out to sea; a plain indication that there was no passage to the N. W.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. II. Being the Second of the First Voyage
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Banks, Joseph, 1743-1820 [Contributor]; Hawkesworth, John, 1715?-1773 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Bannon ignored the note, and all day Monday expected Grady's appearance at the office. He did not come, but when Bannon reached his boarding-house
quoteLast: , he found Grady in his room waiting for him.

quoteFirst: The Philadelphia lay within half gun-shot of the bashaw's castle, and was guarded by several cruisers and gun-boats. The Intrepid entered the harbor alone,
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , and succeeded in getting near the Philadelphia, between ten and eleven o'clock, without having awakened suspicion of her hostile designs. This vessel had been captured from the Tripolitans, and, assuming on this occasion her former national appearance, was permitted to warp alongside.
title: Great Events in the History of North and South America
author: Goodrich, Charles A. (Charles Augustus), 1790-1862

quoteLast: It was found that no further progress was possible, and that there was no help for it but to pass the night in the carriages under the shelter of the station. quoteFirst: For some time provisions in the town showed serious signs of running short, but by a laudable system of mutual accommodation between the residents and tradespeople any actual privation was averted. quoteLast: on Monday night, also blocked at Ivybridge Station, were located in the village, but some of the passengers, as late as Thursday evening, were still in search of lodgings. The railway guards and drivers were also in dire straits, and Mr.
title:

quoteLast: Stones at this time fell very thick at Sang’ir--some of them as large as two fists, but generally not larger than walnuts. Between 9 and 10 P. M.

quoteFirst: We carried the sleeping-bags round and found a mere hollow in the rock-face, with a shingle floor sloping at a steep angle to the sea. There we prepared a hot meal, and when the food was finished I ordered the men to turn in. The time was now
quoteLast: , and I took the first watch beside the _James Caird_, which was still afloat in the tossing water just off the beach.
title: South: The Story of Shackleton's Last Expedition, 1914-1917
author: Shackleton, Ernest Henry, Sir, 1874-1922

quoteFirst: On reaching New York,
quoteLast: , I bent my steps towards the Washington hotel in Broadway, and found my trunks and keys were in the possession of the landlord, Mr Ward. After having seen some of the most celebrated hotels in the States, such as the Tremont at Boston, and Mr Head’s at Philadelphia, none of them pleased me so much as the Washington hotel.
title: A tour through North America
author: Shirreff, Patrick, 1791-1876

quoteFirst: Herter was doing the decoration, and it was extraordinarily fine. After a while we got the engines and boilers and wires all done, and the lights in position, before the house was quite finished, and thought we would have an exhibit of the light.

quoteLast: we lit up, and it was very good. Mr. Vanderbilt and his wife and some of his daughters came in, and were there a few minutes when a fire occurred.
